Maiden of the downcast eye,</br>Who, when ev'ning draweth nigh,</br>Windest oft thy lonely way</br>'Neath the sober twilight grey,</br>Pursuing still the lonely road</br>By human footsteps seldom trod:</br>By the hills or shady woods,</br>Dreary cells and haunted floods;</br>By the church-yard's lonely bound,</br>Wand'ring o'er the cheerless ground—</br>Where oft as vulgar stories tell</br>From isles the midnight spectres yell;</br>Or where some stalwart ruins nod,</br>Or wealth and grandeur once th' abode,</br>Delighted with the dismal howl</br>Of ravens, and the hooting owl.—</br>Come, Melancholy, sober maid!</br>In all thy winning charms array'd,</br>Come sweet maid, nor once disdain</br>To take me in thy pensive train.</br>
